newsitem.title: USA: Dow ends slightly higher as U.S. stocks stem slide.
newsitem.headline: Dow ends slightly higher as U.S. stocks stem slide.

text.p: U.S. blue chips finished slightly higher on Tuesday, pausing for breath after their sharp two-session sell-off.

The Dow industrials rose 28 points to close unofficially at 6611. Analysts were quick to caution, however, that the gains put only a small dent in the nearly 300-point drop the Dow industrials have suffered since last Thursday.
And several said that, despite the welcome respite, the outlook will remain extremely uncertain at least until the questions that triggered the decline go unanswered.

"My sense is we're still in the midst of a painful period that still has a way to go," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Co. "But there's still a lot of uncertainty ahead and will be until we have a better handle on what the Federal Reserve will do next."
Analysts noted that pharmaceutical and finance stocks posted a solid day, notable because the groups have ridden lead-car through the market's roller-coaster ride this year.
"The two leadership groups, banks and drugs, were trying to reassert their leadership today," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.
Chase Manhattan Corp gained 1-5/8 to 95-1/2, Citicorp rose 4-1/4 to 112-1/2 and Dow component J.P. Morgan & Co Inc added 1-5/8 to 99-7/8.
Among drug companies, Dow stock Merck and Co Inc rose 2-3/8 to 86-5/8 and Pfizer Inc rose 7/8 to 85.
Another key sector, technology, failed to fully shake off the effects of its malaise. Analysts said any real reversal in the downturn would likely first take root among tech stocks.
"I think anyone watching for a bottom should watch the techs," said Richard Cripps chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker.
"Last July, the techs were the first group to go lower, first to bottom and first to turn higher again," he said.

While the group as a whole failed to match the modest rally in blue chips, some of the sector's bellwether stocks did show signs of life. Microsoft Corp rose 1-9/16 to 93-1/4 and Intel Corp rose 3/16 to 139-5/16.

Interest rates edged a trace lower on the day, with the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond easing two basis points to 7.08 percent, despite a stronger-than-expected National Association of Purchasing Management report today.
But with critical monthly payrolls, wage and unemployment data due Friday, the interest rate outlook remains far from clear leaving market matters looking anything but certain.
"We're probably going to have more days like today for a while, up 20 points and then down 20," Bleier said. "But if rates go through 7.20 percent, all bets are off."

Among individual issues, database software firm Informix Corp sank 5-7/32 to 9-29/32 and electronic systems design software maker Quickturn Design Systems Inc lost 7-3/4 to 8-1/4, both after profit warnings.
Catalina Marketing Corp, a provider of in-store electronic marketing programs for consumer-goods companies, sank 10-3/4 to 29-7/8, also after warning of disappointing quarterly results.

Embattled Canadian mining company Bre-X Minerals Ltd rebounded a bit, rising 3/4 to 2-1/2 on Nasdaq after being halted all day Monday. Frantic trading in the stock caused computers at the Toronto Stock Exchange to crash.
The S&P 500 index rose 2.52 points to 759.64.
The Nasdaq Composite fell 4.77 points to 1216.93.
((-- Wall Street desk, 212-859-1730))
